Column: 265

'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:–

 

     "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the Second Session of this Parliament.".' – [Mr Michael Palmer].

 

     Question again proposed.

 

     Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, as I stand before this House, I cannot help but to feel a sense of mission. A mission placed on our shoulders by our President, which is to rethink new ways, to search for creative ideas and to prepare for a new beginning as he reminded us and I quote, "When the storm clears, we cannot expect the world to be as before." I thank the President for throwing this challenge to us and I am confident we will respond with a united voice and emerge stronger as we have always done in the past.

 

     I speak from my heart as a Singaporean, as a woman, and as mother. I begin with our policy on education.

 

     If there is one Ministry which has seen the most changes in policies over the years, it is the Ministry of Education. We have seen how streaming our students have or have not worked in the primary school, hence, the change was made.  As we have recognised that individual student peaks at different levels for different talents then we should not stream them based on the overall performance.  Streaming does more than segregating the child educationally.  Streaming separates the child from the people he or she mixes with. It channels the child into a mental tunnel and, in the process, inhibits self-confidence and self-esteem. A child whose self-confidence is shattered will be scarred and that takes a heavy toll on him psychologically.  The

Column:266

child grows up with the belief that he is a man of dull mind. Hence, in my view, the adverse effect of streaming  has more than absorbed its advantages.

 

     Look at other alternatives. Now that we have more resources as we move up the ladder economically and, with improved information  technology and the  good experience we have with the modular system (presently used  in the Polytechnics and Universities), I ask that the Ministry of Education review its policy and consider the adoption of the modular system into our secondary schools.  This will greatly help our students to devote their focus on the subjects that suit their standards and do well, and then move on to the next level of subjects.  Here I am asking for banding of the students at subject level.  The child who takes Mathematics at Level 1 would be together with his/her friends who are comfortable at that level.  However, in the next lesson, he/she would be taking, say, English at a higher level or highest level in view of his/her literacy skill.  In this manner, the child would not only have a wider opportunity of interaction among his peers but would be able to learn and recognise the strength and weaknesses of his peers and learn to interact and respect each other for their individual capabilities. 

 

     It is easy to stay in a comfort zone but it takes courage to venture forward and explore new avenues in a constantly evolving social environment.  The children are the foundation of our society.  How we progress, how we prosper in the future will depend on what we give to our children and how we prepare them now.

 

     Next, I would like to compliment  MOE for doing away with examinations at the lower primary levels, in Primary 1 and 2.  Although the emphasis is on learning life skills, I would like to urge the Ministry to give the children time to participate in mass sports.  We should give them the foundation in character building through

Column:267

sports, where they learn about team work, how to cope with losing and winning, and develop healthy bodies. We should not try to nurture them to go into excellence in sports in school.  This  role should be played by the National Sports Association to handle the grooming and training for excellence in sports. The aim of schools should be to provide each child a chance to play a sport well in school. Presently, our primary schools are selecting children for excellence in sports as early as Primary 2 and this must be changed.

 

     Next, preservation of our family unit.  Mr Speaker, Sir, in Mandarin.

 

     (In Mandarin):  [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A*. ] The Eastern societies have always emphasised the need for strong family relationships.  They face challenges together – if any family member needs help or any relative needs assistance, if they are having financial problems or if they need daily necessities like fuel, rice, oil and salt – our parents, brothers and sisters, cousins, even relatives are always ready to lend a helping hand.  They are duty-bound to help one another in the family.  They feel the need to stay connected as a family and succeed together.  They will not allow their family members to land in a predicament.  They try to avoid having to seek external subsistence or government allowance or to be put in a tight spot unless they are at their wits' end!  And then, they will take action.  Also, they will try their best to look for opportunities through their own efforts and not blame God and Man, meaning, blame anyone and everything but not one self.  Such sentiment has gradually thinned in our society after we moved into the HDB estates.  Some have even lost touch with their family members. 
 
     Over the course of the past few years, I have been a Member of Parliament for

Column:268

some time.  During the Meet-the-People Sessions with my residents, I often hear parents complain that their children will not look after them.  They criticise their parents for being naggy, they treat them as a burden and throw them out of the house.  Or they will move out of their parents' house.  Some parents cannot get along with their sons' wives, and they are not willing to take care of their grandsons because these old folks want some free time and space for themselves.  Some elderly people have many sons and daughters, numerous siblings but none of them look after the daily lives of these elderly persons.  To the old folks, one day seems like a year. Each time I hear the families' stories, I am at a loss and I feel very sad.  What can we do to help build up family bonds?

 

     Mr Speaker, we hope to help more of those elderly residents, many of whom are the low income.  And so, before the Chinese Lunar New Year, the constituency will approach business organisations or foundations for donations.  Such contributions will be distributed as "hong baos" for the low-income elderly so that they will have a happy festival.  However, those with financial ability feel that "hong baos" are something they must have and they insist on it.  This makes me very worried.  Do we care too little for those less fortunate in the community? During the Chinese New Year Festival, many Singaporeans go on overseas vacations with their families.  If the whole family wants to take the opportunity to travel, I think that is okay.  What we are worried about is that some Singaporeans are away for overseas vacations to avoid the etiquette and customs of the Lunar New Year.  They want to run away from the Chinese New Year.  If Singaporeans continue to do so, it will inevitably affect their family bonding and relationships between relatives and friends.  This will affect the building up of family bonds and values.  Eventually, it will be more difficult to build a caring and loving family. 
 

Column:269

     Mr Speaker, I hope that MCYS will relook into its provisions for single-parent families, give more care to the children whose parents are divorced.  A divorced man with children may want to get married a second time.  But he may not be able to provide for alimony.  This means that the ex-wife and children have to face financial difficulties.  Can we consider imposing stricter regulations on those men who want to get married a second time?  We should ensure that they have the financial ability to pay alimony to support his ex-wife and children.  Statistics have shown that the rate of divorce cases has increased from 6.1% in 2001 to 8.3% 2008. I also wish to highlight that in Eastern societies, monogamy is the foundation of the family and family values.  This is something we hold in esteem. 
 
     Mr Speaker, Sir, as we prepare ourselves for the economic recovery, we should also look into how we can carry forward and enhance family cohesion to promote family bonding and ties.  As the saying goes, "The people are the foundation of country". This ideology is the push factor for our continuous success.

     Dr Loo Choon Yong (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the Motion of Thanks to the President.  I would also like to comment on some aspects of his Address.

 

     The constitutional safeguards requiring the President's approval came into effect in November 1991, but were invoked for the first time only this year – in January 2009 – when the Government sought to use part of the reserves to fund the Job Credits Scheme and the Special Risk-Sharing Initiative.  The President gave his in-principal approval for the drawdown on 21st January, the day before Budget 2009 was presented to Parliament.  The

Column:270

amount of drawdown from past reserves was S$4.9 billion.  This House passed the Supply Bill and Supplementary Supply Bill on 13th February, approving the Budget.  The President gave his assent to both the Supply Act and the Supplementary Supply Act on 9th March, effectively giving his formal approval for the drawdown of S$4.9 billion from past reserves.

 

     During the global financial meltdown in 2008, the Government announced in October that up to S$150 billion of past reserves have been set aside to guarantee deposits in Singapore until the end of 2010.  The guarantee covered all Singapore Dollar and foreign currency deposits of individual and non-bank customers in banks, financial companies and merchant banks licensed by MAS. This move was to give banks in Singapore a level playing field with those countries where the Government had introduced similar guarantees, Hong Kong and Australia.

 

     Whilst this guarantee did not constitute an actual draw on the reserves, it was nevertheless a contingent liability and should any of the depository financial institutions fail, the Government will have to make good the deposit. The Government prudently sought the President’s approval and he approved this guarantee.  I would like to commend the Government for obtaining the President’s approval prior to guaranteeing bank deposits. Otherwise, in the unfortunate situation where a MAS licensed bank actually fail, the guarantee would have been called upon and would have to be honoured by the Government. The President will then be presented with a fait accompli.

 

     Sir, in early 1999, when Singapore was in recession as a result of the Asian Financial Crisis, then President Ong Teng Cheong had said that he would approve the Government’s request to draw on past reserves to finance recession measures, if

Column:271

asked. However, the then Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said there was no need to dip into past reserves as the Government had accumulated sufficient funds in current reserves.  In November 2001, Singapore was again in recession.  Then Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong raised the possibility of having to use past reserves to deal with the recession as the Government had only been re-elected to a fresh term. This turned out to be unnecessary again.


     The above examples showed the Government has been very prudent in managing our reserves and I commend them. This global financial crisis has in fact demonstrated clearly the wisdom of the philosophy to spend tax dollars wisely, accumulating any surpluses, invest them thoughtfully and draw on them only in extreme situations. The reserves form part of our national economic defence and, if safeguarded wisely and managed carefully, it can provide for the economic safety net for our country and our citizens.  As this constitutional safeguard has been in place since 1991, some 18 years ago, and we have drawn on the past reserves only once, we should learn from this event and further strengthen this important institution. 

 

     Recently, Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong was reported as putting up three "No" signs for drawing on past reserves:

 

     (a) No drawdown to support social assistance programme;

 

     (b) No drawdown to fund permanent programmes, no matter how meritorious; and

 

     (c) No drawdown except under dire circumstances that require one-off extra ordinary measures.

 

     I find Senior Minister Goh’s three "No"s useful in guiding our thinking regarding this matter. I would like to

Column:272

propose two more "Nos" to help strengthen these guidelines:


     (d) No drawdown without Parliament’s approval; and

 

     (e) No distinction between actual drawdown and guarantees or any other contingent liabilities on the Government or any part of it.


     I propose the additional "No"s to ensure that Parliament will always have a chance to debate any actual or potential drawdowns. People should be informed and their elected representatives should have a chance to raise questions and make comments on the Government’s intention to draw down on past reserves, even if the President has indicated his willingness to approve.

 

 

An emergency session of Parliament can be convened to discuss an urgent drawdown or any urgent guarantee.  The fifth "No" will prevent the kind of fait accompli  situation that a future President may find himself in, if the Government of the day does not seek his approval before granting guarantee or taking on any contingent liability.

 

    Sir, it is imperative that as a young nation of 50 years, we need to keep building upon our national institutions.  Institution building is a long and unending process.  It is necessary to build these institutions so that we will have the social cohesion and social ballast to see Singapore through difficult and challenging times.  The Presidential approval to draw down from past reserves, or better known as the "two keys" system, is one such institution.

     Sir, I was quite disappointed when a certain hon. Member in this House suggested in the Budget debate that the President’s second key was automatically turned when the Government’s first key was turned.  He even wondered in this House if the second key had always been

Column:273

left on the safe!  It is one thing for Singaporeans to be witty in coffeeshop conversations or for Mr Brown to satirise any aspect of our national life but it is quite another for a Member of this House to make such an irresponsible suggestion.  In fact, as a leader of the community, one should explain to the less informed the conduct of such a serious exercise and strengthen our collective faith in this institution.  Sir, the fact that the President agreed to draw down from past reserves within a few days does not ipso facto, make it a mindless turn of the second key.  The type of urgent and dire circumstances that will require such a drawdown on past reserves will always require the Government as well as the President to consider the circumstances and act expeditiously and appropriately.  The decision to guarantee all bank deposits have to be made quickly as other jurisdictions move, otherwise most deposits will move to countries which guarantee them.  The hon. Member should know that billions of dollars can be moved with the press of the "return" key on a computer.


     Sir, I believe the hon. Member in question has confused speed of decision with the independence of decision.  He should know that decisions even when made contemporaneously by two persons can be different or similar and, when similar, it can still be the result of independent thinking. 

     Further, the President does not act alone.  He is advised by the Council of Presidential Advisers (CPA), which consists of eight distinguished former public servants and civic leaders whose reputation for independent thinking, independent judgment, good sense and integrity is beyond reproach.  It is the CPA’s duty to advise the President on all drawdowns from past reserves. 

Column:274

     Sir, I am more than satisfied that the second key of the President has not been automatically turned when the first key of the Government was turned this time.  It was a deliberate, well-considered and independent decision.

 

     Sir, the President’s speech was titled "Building our Future in an Uncertain World", and he called for "Enhancing our Economic Competitiveness".  Building the right infrastructure – be it great airport, seaport, highways, MRT or ultra high speed broadband, incentivising R&D spending, improving education through building more schools and universities to educate and train our young, better and affordable healthcare for Singaporeans – all these are important and helpful in enhancing our economic competitiveness.  I commend the Government on these efforts.

 

     Sir, recently a former Chairman of EDB was quoted as saying that Singapore does not need local entrepreneurs.  He said that we can continue to attract MNCs to Singapore and they will provide the economic growth for Singapore.  Furthermore, he was reported to have said that local entrepreneurs will not hesitate to move their production elsewhere if situations are more favourable elsewhere.

     Sir, I find it difficult to understand his call.  I hope it is mere romantic reminiscence as he recounted his early days of courting foreign MNCs to set up production bases in Singapore to take advantage of our lower costs of production here.  He, together with other EDB pioneers, have done well and ought to be recognised and acknowledged for the great execution of our then policy of attracting MNCs to provide FDI to create jobs for our people.  But I also hope that this romantic reminiscence is not meant as a prescription for tomorrow.  Sir, the world has changed in these last few years.  We all know it will be a different world after this global financial crisis. 

Column:275

MNCs come and go according to their own interests, not Singapore’s interests.  In the new world, local enterprises like MNCs must locate their distributed value chain where it makes most sense.  That is why we need to review our strategies and formulate new specific strategies to grow our economy in the new world order.  I am glad the President has called on us all, in public and private sectors, to put our minds together, and he is confident we will "develop new ideas to help Singapore transform, advance and prosper" in its next phase of growth.


     The 2001 Economic Review Committee under the chairmanship of the then Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, dedicated 17 pages of its report on "nurturing an entrepreneurial and creative Singapore".  I am happy to note that many of the recommendations have been implemented.  A Minister for Entrepreneurship (Minister Raymond Lim) was appointed and ACE, a public-private sector collaboration to promote local entrepreneurship, was formed in 2003.  The international press mocked us for requiring Government to be involved even in something like promoting entrepreneurship.  They think it as an oxymoron.  Local entrepreneurs, like Wong Ngit Liong, Inderjit Singh, Kwek Leng Beng, Kim Faulkner, Ong Peng Tsim, Elim Chew, Sunny Verghee, Patrick Daniel and Kenny Yap, were involved.  Today, the local entrepreneurship scene has evolved.  The entrepreneurial mindset is more evident in Singapore.  There are networking opportunities, financing and venture capital opportunities, Government loan and grant schemes, loan-securitisation programmes, mentorship and referral services.  Even schools are promoting entrepreneurship amongst their students.  Today, start-ups find easier access to capital financing in various forms and ACRA has reported much higher new firms formation.


     So, we, therefore, must continue to promote local entrepreneurship in order to

Column:276

grow our economy and "help Singapore transform, advance and prosper in its next phase of growth".  Many hon. Members of this House, like Inderjit Singh, Ahmad Magad, Edwin Khew and others have tirelessly and repeatedly asked for more support to help start-ups and SMEs grow.  Sir, the start-up company is usually small, agile, founded by passionate high energy and often highly creative person and friends.  Whilst they are all very sure they are on to the next great thing, the next Google, they are often wrong. Start-ups fail most of the time.  It is usually a bad idea or bad execution, often both bad idea and bad execution.  However there are also the occasional great idea and great execution and when this happens, successful enterprises result.  So this is the story of Venture Manufacturing, Hyflux, Creative Technologies, OSIM, Raffles Education. Others have taken over old family businesses, grafted on them modern management methods and governance and grown them into robust regional businesses.  Banyan Tree, Eu Yan Sang, Charles & Keith, Coffee Bean are some examples.


     Sir, these local enterprises belong to Singapore.  Some of them are listed on our Stock Exchange.   They pay taxes here and they set up their headquarters here because this is their home, home of their founders and owners.  The owners, when they make money, build their physical homes here, park and spend their wealth here and employ quite a lot of Singaporeans at home and abroad.  Most of the senior management positions are occupied by Singaporeans.  They use the services of Singaporean lawyers in Singapore law firms, Singapore accountants in the big four accounting firms, Singapore banks, and I am sure they buy Singapore goods and services reflexly both here and overseas. 

     Local companies compete with each other but they also learn from each other and we are beginning to see signs of

Column:277

collaboration overseas even as they compete here at home.  As the economic space is greater in the region than here in Singapore, regionalisation is no longer a luxury.  Every company needs to have a regional strategy if it aspires to grow.  The region, Vietnam, China, India and Indonesia, still offers great opportunities for Singapore companies.  But the window of opportunities may not be opened forever. Soon we may have to face competition from adventurous and daring entrepreneurs from China, India and Vietnam in other countries who, too, aspire to grow and prosper outside their own national borders.

     Sir, besides start-ups, SMEs and larger local enterprises, there are other bigger local enterprises that can play a part to help us grow our economy, our economic resilience and competitiveness.  The Government-linked Companies (GLCs), like SIA, SingTel, ST Technologies, CapitaLand, Ascott, Keppel Corporation, Sembawang Corporation, DBS Bank, are big regional or even global companies.  They have penetrated foreign markets significantly and they have competed successfully against other foreign market players.  They should continue to push and grow further overseas.  They have the financial muscles, the management depth and the competitive value proposition to grow and thrive.  They represent the external wing of our economy.


     Sir, besides producing better total shareholders return (TSR) for Temasek, I believe they can also contribute more to the Singapore economy.  Many smaller enterprises can benefit from associating with and learning from these GLCs.  I understand that CapitaLand actively supports smaller companies to venture overseas to markets where CapitaLand themselves are established.  You will find many familiar local food outlets like Bread Talk, Bali Thai, Food Republic, and

Column:278

retailers like Osim, Aussino, Spectacle Hut, and SK Jewellery establishing themselves in the food courts and shopping malls of the various "Raffles Cities" that CapitaLand has established in China.  I also know of Singapore architectural, engineering, quantity surveyor and legal firms that have ventured into the region when they won appointments from CapitaLand.  So, too, have many Singaporean subcontractors, including door makers and interior decorators.  I have no doubt that these transactions are carried out on a win-win, competitive basis.  I hope more GLCs will follow CapitaLand’s example and help open up more economic space for our smaller Singaporean companies.


     We should also undertake an indepth study to assess how these GLCs are adding value to our economy as a whole.  I suspect they are contributing more to our economy than paying taxes for their profits and paying dividends to their shareholders.  If this is indeed the case, then we should aggressively promote more such GLCs and larger private sector enterprises to go regional first and then eventually go global.

 

 

     Sir, being a non-economist, I was very reassured to read Prof. Linda Lim’s article "Why local entrepreneurs are vital" in Straits Times, 12th May, this year.  Prof. Lim, a Singaporean, is Professor of Strategy at the Ross School of Business, University of Michigan.  She said, "Home-grown entrepreneurs are more likely to create jobs for Singaporeans for each dollar invested.  Their investments will be less capital – and foreign talent-dependent, and less volatile than those of global MNCs.  They would be more likely to purchase inputs and services locally than globally, creating a market for other local entrepreneurs and developing the services sector, the main engine of growth and employment in mature economies.  More local stock market listings will give Singaporeans more

Column:279

options for investment."  I fully agree with her sentiments and she concluded the article by saying "MNCs, foreign capital and foreign talents have done a lot for Singapore. We need and should continue to welcome them.  But openness to foreigners does not mean that we do not need home-grown entrepreneurs.  We do."  I agree with her sentiments.


     Sir, in the post crisis new world, I believe the Singapore economy would be better served if these GLCs are managed as strategic assets, with KPIs which also reward them for adding value to the Singapore economy as well as rewarding them for their profits and EVA growth.  When appropriately incentivised, we will see management of GLCs help nurture other local enterprises and, in the process, help grow and strengthen the Singapore economy.  As this nurturing activity requires a different mindset, a different time horizon, different reflexes from that of managing a fund purely for maximising total shareholder value, I call on the Government and Temasek to consider holding all strategic GLCs under a different division with a different mission, and a separate management team with different KPIs.  If these strategic assets continue to add value to the Singapore economy beyond total shareholder returns, then I would strongly suggest that we keep them and resist any temptation to sell them for a profit, especially in times when operating profits look sub-optimal.  However, if this proposal creates difficulties or confusion of having under the same roof two big strong divisions with differing missions, different management teams with different KPIs, then I urge the Government to consider having two separate Temaseks – Temasek I and Temasek II – each with a separate board and management team to execute the different missions and strategies and both can add value to Singapore, albeit in different ways.
 

Column:280

     Sir, I am sure that such a proposal has been considered by Temasek and the Government before and found not appropriate.  Sir, if we really want to build "a future in an uncertain world", I urge the Government to leave no stone unturned in reviewing our economy and our competitiveness.  Sir, I recommend that the Government gives this proposal serious consideration again.  I promise to be satisfied, if after turning the stone, the Government put back the stone exactly to where it was.


     Sir, the NMP scheme was introduced in March 1990 to add diversity of views and opinions to Parliament in its deliberations.  There were reservations, particularly amongst Government backbenchers, that the scheme was tantamount to allowing a back door entry into Parliament.  Opposition members were also apprehensive about the scheme for their own reasons.  So the then Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong made a concession that each new Parliament will decide if it wishes to have Nominated Members of Parliament.

 

     The scheme has been in place for 19 years.  It currently provides for Parliament to have up to nine NMPs, each serving a term of two and a half years.  To date, 49 NMPs have served.  Some have contributed more than others.  NMP Walter Woon outstandingly moved a Private Members Bill that is today the Maintenance of Parents Act.  Some penetrating questions have been asked and quite a few suggestions have been made at Supply Bill debates and Committee of Supply debates.  NMPs contribute even outside this House officiating at functions, events and certain NMPs also help at EGMs!  Collectively, I think Parliament and Singapore has been well served through the diversity of opinions and views brought into this House and onto our national debates.

Column:281

     My observation is that, by and large, NMPs' diverse views have been non-partisan and pro-Singapore.  It is important that views expressed by NMPs to be "independent and non-partisan" as intended in the Constitution.


     Sir, I believe it is time for us to accept the NMP scheme as a permanent feature of our Parliament.  We have tried, tested and tweaked the scheme for 19 years.  How much longer do we need to wait to know it is good?  I therefore call upon the Government to introduce appropriate amendments to the Constitution to do so.  As the President has said, "our political system is not set in stone.  Singapore politics must evolve over time", I believe this is the right time to make the NMP scheme permanent.

 

     Sir, I support the motion.

 

 

     Ms Indranee Rajah (Tanjong Pagar): Thank you, Mr Speaker, for allowing me to join in the debate.

 

     In his Address, President Nathan outlined the challenges that lie ahead for Singapore as well as the broad strategies and framework of the policies which the Government intends to follow to meet the challenges facing us.

 

     On politics, President Nathan noted that our basic system is sound because it encourages strong and effective government, and is responsive.  He also noted that our political system is not set in stone and that Singapore politics must evolve over time as the world and our society change.

 

     Clearly, the Singapore of today is a very different one from the Singapore of 1965 when we first became independent.  Along the way, we have made many changes on the political landscape to adapt to our system.  These have included things like the GRCs, NMP scheme and

Column:282

the NCMP scheme.  All of these have been in response to our changing needs over the years.  One thing, though, must remain constant, which is the need for clean and honest government.  In this connection, Mr Low Thia Khiang, the Member for Hougang, in his speech yesterday advanced the proposition that only an elected Opposition can provide effective checks and balances.

 

     In support of this proposition, he made six points.  He said the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) currently dominates the House, can amend the Constitution freely and controls key levers of power in the country.  Second, what if one day PAP were to abuse its powers, trample on people's rights and become corrupt?  What can people do then?  He noted then maybe the CPIB has a role to play, but suggested that if the CPIB is under the purview of the Prime Minister's Office, it cannot play an effective checking role.  Fourth, in his Mandarin speech, he noted that some believe the ruling party would be able to check itself and it was not a nest of snakes and rats – not very polite.  And that even if it were to break up, the remaining half could still run the country.  However, he argued in response that the best way was to have external checks and balances in the system in the form of more effective Opposition presence.  He also called Singapore democracy a one-legged duck – more animals.

 

     Next, with respect to the PAP's argument that it was not responsible for helping the Opposition grow, he said that this smacked of a winner-takes-all, loser-is-a-bandit approach.  And with respect to the argument that losing Opposition candidates can still be appointed as NCMPs, he said this was not enough as the role of the Opposition is not merely to reflect the views and feelings of its people, and that only by having a geographical constituency would an Opposition party be able to grow a support base and strengthen its

Column:283

competency, and these MPs need to have weekly Meet-the-People Sessions to be able to appreciate people's real concerns as well as to assess the effectiveness of Government's policy.

 

     There are several fallacies in the arguments advanced by Mr Low and I would like to address them.  His main proposition is that only an elected Opposition can provide effective checks and balances and keep the Government free of corruption.  In a nutshell, he is saying that Opposition in Parliament equals or ensures clean and non-corrupt government.  That assumption is not only simplistic, it is simply incorrect.  If that were true, then why is it that in many other countries, which have two-party or multi-party systems, there is nevertheless still problems of deep-seated and endemic corruption.  If it were so simple, and all you need to have is an Opposition to have checks and balances, then why is it that in these other countries which have strong and vociferous Opposition parties in Parliament, that they still have problems with corruption?  Going by Mr Low's argument, the logical outcome is that in every other country in the world with an Opposition, they should be squeaky clean, and in Singapore, in which a large majority of the Parliament comes from a single party, then Singapore should be the most corrupt country in the world.  That, as we know, is not the case.  And it has been widely acknowledged, not just by us, but internationally, that Singapore today, with the PAP Government at the helm, is one of the least corrupt systems in the world, and that there is a high degree of respect for the Government and Members of Parliament.  And that is not just the PAP Members of Parliament but also the NCMPs, the Nominated Members of Parliament and the Opposition Members of Parliament.

 

     Since we have only two elected Opposition Members in Parliament, the fact that we currently have a honest and

Column:284

clean Government clearly cannot be attributable to the Opposition.  It must obviously be due to something else.  And the question is:  What?  It is due to the fact that the PAP Government has set for itself and its Members of Parliament a high degree of accountability and integrity.  What is it that keeps us from the path of corruption?  From personal experience, I can tell you that it is the values taught to me by my parents, the values imbued in me in school, which is an education system set up by the PAP Government, and by my training as a lawyer within the legal system, which was set up by the PAP Government.

 

     On becoming an MP, what keeps me from the path of corruption, aside from the things I have already mentioned, is the fact that I am conscious that as an elected Member of Parliament, I am accountable to the people of Singapore.  By electing me as their MP, my constituents have placed their faith and trust in me, something that is not to be held lightly.  I have no doubt that all of my fellow MPs and, most certainly, the PAP ones, feel the same way.  All of us who sit in this Parliament hold our positions in trust for the people of Singapore and the members of our constituency.  And it is also because the leaders of the PAP expect of all the PAP Members, including its Members of Parliament, the highest standard of integrity.  That is not to say that some do not fall short.  We all know of the case of a Minister who, in the past, had accepted bribes.  He paid a very heavy price for that.  But the point that what keeps us focused on the path of clean, honest Government is that the party and the system expect it of us, and the system has inherent checks and balances to deal with it.

 

     After the last General Election in 2006, people may recall the letter from the Prime Minister to all PAP Members of Parliament, released to the media, which

Column:285

reminded us of our responsibility and accountability to the people of Singapore and the need to maintain honesty and integrity.  These are the things that keep us on the straight and narrow.  It is not the fact that there is an Opposition.  It is the value system that we have, the concept of honest, clean Government with integrity which is a concept that was advanced and implemented by the PAP from the time of internal self-Government and independence to today.  And this concept is now taken as an axiomatic requirement by all Singaporeans of Government and it is something that was introduced by the PAP Government.

 

     Mr Low asked the question: What if one day PAP were to abuse its powers and trample on people's rights and become corrupt?  What can people do then?  The answer is: If that day ever comes, then the people are at liberty to vote out the PAP Government, and should do so in that situation.  The premise of Mr Low's suggestion is flawed.  He is really saying: just in case PAP becomes corrupt in the future, then people have better vote for the Opposition now.  But if you apply the same logic, then the argument can also be made that if you vote in the Opposition, then they may become corrupt in the future.  So in order to avoid that, you might as well vote for PAP now.  It does not make any sense.  What Mr Low is suggesting is that people should vote on the basis of speculation and this is premised on the assumption that Opposition equals clean government.  I have already shown why Opposition does not necessarily equal clean government.  And as it is speculation, people cannot vote on the basis of speculation.  People have to vote on the basis of track record and trust, and that trust must be earned and kept by our politicians at every stage of the way.  If the PAP keeps faith with the people of Singapore, then why should the people of Singapore not vote for

Column:286

them?  On the other hand, if the PAP does not keep faith with the people of Singapore, then they should be voted out and deservedly so.  But that should be done at the point when it is shown that faith has not been kept, and not on the basis of "what ifs".

 

     Mr Low called the Singapore democracy a one-legged duck.  The democracy that we have today is a democracy which the people of Singapore have voted for and which they have helped to shape, because the system takes into account Singaporeans' feedback and our changing social mores.  Quite apart from the fact that it is not very polite to call the choice of Singaporeans a one-legged duck, I would give Singaporeans a lot more credit than Mr Low has done.

 

 

Singaporeans know and understand what they vote for.  If Singaporeans do not approve of something, they also have no hesitation in showing their disapproval and making their views known.  The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) saga and the AWARE sage are just two instances of where when Singaporeans have felt strongly about something, they make it very clear and very plain.

 

     The suggestion that if the CPIB is under the purview of the Prime Minister's Office, it cannot play an effective checking role is misconceived.  When the Prevention of Corruption Act was passed, the very reason why the CPIB was put under the purview of the Prime Minister's Office was precisely so that it could play an effective role.  By making it directly accountable to the Prime Minister's Office, the CPIB, unlike the other departments, do not have to report to any other Ministers or Ministries.  They go straight to the top, and that enables them to carry out their duties effectively without fear or favour.

 

     Mr Low felt that having NCMPs is not enough because the Opposition is not

Column:287

     Mr Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I join Members in support of the Motion of Thanks to the President.


     In the last three years, the Singapore economy has been put to a "stress test", with both extremes tested in every sense of the word. We started the new term of Government in 2006 worried about high inflation and the severe bottlenecks caused by our then-strong GDP growth.


     Fast forward to 2009, and our worries have shifted dramatically to growing unemployment and excess capacity. The economy has never been this volatile. Sharp growth has given way to deep contraction. The pace of GDP contraction in the last two quarters has been unprecedented, with our national income

Column:291

contracting 16.4% in Q4 last year and another 14.6% for Q1 this year.


     Thankfully, the unemployment situation thrown up by this downturn has not been too serious. So far, the retrenchment figures have neither been as bad as past recessions nor as significant as previously feared. I must commend the Government for taking the bold decision to dip into our national reserves to fund one-off assistance measures such as the Jobs Credit Scheme. Such programmes have no doubt provided companies with some financial cheer amidst all the gloom, and obliged large companies which  have received the Jobs Credit to hold on to their staff.


     Nevertheless, this crisis has again highlighted that we are not as economically resilient as we had hoped ourselves to be. As a small and open export-oriented economy, our fate in this economic storm depends almost entirely on the fortunes of those bigger and stronger than us. Without major world markets such as the US, Europe and China leading the way, there is very little chance we can get out of the wilderness on our own.


     It is therefore timely again for us to do some soul-searching and take a hard look at our economic strategy, particularly with regard to building stronger economic resilience. Is our economy diversified enough to power on even with our main growth engines down? Have we done enough to nurture our home-grown companies? Are we still overly reliant on foreign multi-national companies to add value to our economy, and in the process leave ourselves vulnerable should they decide to pack up when the going gets tough?


     Just as the President has said in his Opening Address, our economic problems will not disappear the moment the economy recovers. Our constraints of

Column:292

limited land and labour could derail our progress once we start growing again. Major developing economies such as China and India, on the other hand, will emerge from the crisis as bigger and stronger competitors, and they will be in a better position than us to pick up the slack.


     Also, we must expect a new world order in the post-crisis economy.  In the US, for example, all signs are pointing to a structural downward shift in consumers’ propensity to spend. On the other hand, we can expect an increase in households’ propensity to save as individuals rebuild their falling net worth. De-leveraging at the private sector will continue to dampen demand. 

 

     So, what are our options?


     In his Address, the President had raised key questions necessary to take Singapore to its next phase of growth. Among them were: one, how can we capitalise on new markets and emerging industries for growth and diversification?  Two, how can we build new capabilities and anchor value in Singapore for the long term?


     Despite our attempts to diversify the economy since 2001, we continue to rely extensively on volatile sectors such as the electronics and manufacturing industries for job and wealth creation. The pharmaceutical sector, which increasingly accounts for a bigger share of our non-oil export, is dependent on a handful of large companies based here. Our export strategy continues to be weighted heavily on developed economies such as the US and Europe, where demand has taken a nosedive since the crisis began. We have suffered as a result of our dependence on global circumstances.


     In the Ministry of Trade and Industry's (MTI) Addendum to the President’s Address, MTI stated that it

Column:293

will step up measures to help our companies expand in markets such as China, India, Southeast Asia and the Middle East. The Government will also enhance efforts to engage and understand emerging markets with potential, such as Latin America and Eastern Europe.  This "cast the net wide" approach is sensible and necessary in building our economic resilience. It gives the economic agencies the opportunity to be re-oriented to these markets, while motivating our local industries to gear up for the export frontiers.


     Besides the new export markets, we should also build emerging industries as new growth areas. One promising emerging industry that I want to zoom into is the sustainable energy sector. With increasing volatility in the price of crude oil and the growing concern on climate change, the global search for alternative clean and efficient energy will pick up speed. Staying at the forefront of the energy technology scene would also help strengthen our energy resilience as we are almost totally dependent on piped gas to power our economy. Building new capabilities on this front could also spur demand for such services as Government, companies and homes look to improve their energy efficiency.

 

     In this aspect, the Government has made some headway through the various support programmes, such as the $20 million grant recently awarded under the Solar Capability Scheme. Pending further breakthroughs in technology, however, the cost of solar energy is still higher than that of conventional sources. Commercial companies would be hard pressed to invest in the solar sector, especially if they are unable to price solar energy competitively. 


     Here is where I hope the Government can come in. We should take reference from the way we introduce our fourth

Column:294

national tap to enhance our water self sufficiency. Desalinated water on its own would not be a viable alternative as it costs more than the traditional source of water or NEWater. To overcome that, PUB entered into a long-term Water Purchase Agreement to buy a certain volume of water at an agreed price so that the company can have a viable long-term business model to base on.


     The Government could look to similar approach to encourage investment in alternative energy by agreeing to off-take a certain amount of electricity powered by, say, solar over a period of time. This will encourage more fixed investments with a longer term horizon, which will also enhance our energy and economic resilience.

    

     In the MTI's Addendum, the Ministry also emphasised the need for a more concerted effort to deepen the capabilities of our companies, so that they can compete on the global stage.  It mentioned that the Government will encourage more foreign MNCs and high-growth companies to anchor their key functions here and partner Singapore-based companies so that they, too, can be part of the Asian growth story.  I fully agree with the Ministry’s strategy, and call on the Government to make this a top priority in our economic action plans in the next few years.


     To anchor the value of these multi-national corporations here, I suggest we adopt a "pick and choose" strategy when chasing the MNC dollar, rather than a "all are welcome" approach. We should offer maximum concessions to MNCs that invest in Singapore with a long-term view. These firms should also be prepared to sink in significant fixed capital expenditure, as well as have a higher share of their earnings retained in Singapore.

    

     To foster the internationalisation of our home-grown companies, we should

Column:295

also incentivise MNCs to partner or form joint ventures with them. Here, again, without the economic agencies acting as middlemen to broker such partnerships, it may be unrealistic to expect these tie-ups to take place organically.


     In our effort to nurture homebred industry champions,

 

 

we should leverage on our strengths.  Notwithstanding other constraints, Singapore does have its competitive advantage in this race.  Besides the presence of talents, excellent infrastructure and a stable Government, Singapore, as a triple A-rated jurisdiction, is also well-endowed with capital.

 

     Our high savings rates, ample reserves and continued foreign capital inflows are a good source of funds for our companies to tap on for expansion and growth.  Even during this financial crisis, our promising companies have little issue raising funds to strengthen their balance sheets. The missing link we have to address is how best to channel such capital into companies, so that we can anchor value in Singapore for the long term.

     Perhaps, this is where our history books can serve as a guide.  In the early years of our industrialisation, state-managed development financing, through the then-Development Bank of Singapore, was available to help promising companies expand and grow.  Many of these firms today are established and successful, contributing significantly to our GDP, and, through the total or partial ownership of Temasek Holdings, remain firmly rooted in Singapore. With such dedication to funding and developing businesses, we were able to establish regional companies, including the high-flying global brand name like Singapore Airlines (SIA).

     Today, the development bank model no longer exists.  Agencies like EDB, SPRING, A-STAR and others have stepped

Column:296

up to fill the void, but their roles are less direct, and the assistance they offer limited. More importantly, while such agencies can help companies obtain financing with more favourable terms, they do not necessarily anchor companies and value in Singapore for the long term.

    In my view, Temasek can play this role of nurturing more regional and global champions, and, in so doing, root them in Singapore.  Since its inception in 1974, Temasek's track record speaks for itself, having been an exemplary steward of the companies it owns.  After 35 years, I think it is opportune time for Temasek to review its role and harness its capital to strengthen the resilience of the Singapore economy.

     While this is admittedly a change from Temasek's current stated role of an investment house with purely commercial objectives, I believe the organisation can make a great difference by producing more respected and admired companies in the region based in Singapore.  

    The benefits of homegrown global brands are exemplified through the likes of smaller European economies, which have generally performed better and are less severely impacted by the global downturn. For example, countries with similar population like Singapore, such as Denmark, Belgium, Finland and Switzerland, have been pretty resilient.

     On closer examination, I noticed that these are also countries whose economies are well-anchored by large homegrown companies headquartered at their cities. They are the same companies brandishing well-established global brands – such as Finland's Nokia and Denmark's Maersk – that play a significant role in keeping their respective national economies humming along.

     For all our tenacity and business acumen, Singapore has yet to exhibit the

Column:297

same kind of resilience. Therefore, our target over the next 10 to 15 years should be to nurture and develop between three and five global brands, similar to the likes of SIA.

     In conclusion, Sir, let me stress that I am not calling for a 180-degree U-turn of our economic strategies.  Our policies are sound and have served us well, and they will continue to do so as we emerge from this crisis.

     However, simply reinventing the wheel is not the ticket to survival in this harsh new era.  Instead, we should expand our economic machinery by playing an active role in fostering the growth of homebred companies; companies that were firmly rooted in Singapore.  Rather than take a backseat and be content to act as a mere source of capital, I urge the Government to take the steering wheel and, if need be, give companies the direction they need at this critical juncture. After all, history has shown that the model works in our circumstances, and there is no reason why we cannot continue to engineer successes.

     So let us be brave and venture out, focus on securing future opportunities and, in so doing, turn our dreams of achieving economic independence into reality.

The Singapore workforce profile has changed over the years.  More Singaporeans are now employed in the positions of the PMETs.  PMETs form the majority today, 51%, compared to 41% 10 years ago.


     There have been numerous programmes introduced recently to help these PMETs to tackle the downturn. We have PCP, PSP and also some recent improvements to the absentee payroll for PMETs undergoing SPUR training.


     Currently, out of the 530,000 union members that NTUC has, about 127,000 of them are PMETs, which means that we represent about 13% of the PMETs. And we understand that they face the challenges of the downturn as well. We have a unit whereby we have officers that deal with workplace issues faced by the PMETs.  They are what we call the General Branch members, not from the unionised companies.  Hence, there is no legal representation for them.  But we could adopt a moral suasion approach when we speak to the companies.

 

     We have seen an increase in the number of cases raised by the PMETs in the last few months.  Most of them query about labour law.  They asked where they can seek help if they are in trouble.  And we have also seen cases where they were retrenched without retrenchment benefit after serving many years in the company or they were being terminated in disguise of retrenchment or they were just told to go on one or two months' unpaid leave, with no visibility whether there will be work when they return.  In most of the cases, what they have wanted to is a listening ear – somebody listens to them – and somewhere they can seek redress and, in most of the cases, there were no proper communications between their employers and them.

 

Column:320

     So, with more than 50% of our resident workforce who are PMETs, I believe it is appropriate for us to have a new thinking on how the PMETs will not be left on their own, and whether more can be done to help the PMETs to ensure that there is fair play and fair treatment at the workplace.


     Sir, we must continue to engage all our workers, whether they are young or old, PMETs or the rank and file.


     This is the 50th year since Singapore has become a self-government state.  That is something we should be proud of.  The Prime Minister in his May Day Rally speech has also mentioned that this is a significant milestone and we should continue to look at what more we could want to achieve together.


     Our workers have rallied behind us all these years.  They have weathered many storms with us. When times are bad, they tighten their belts.  When times have improved, they would want to be remembered of the sacrifices they have made and also to share the fruits of the labour.  The President said that we will want all citizens to have full opportunities to achieve their aspirations.  Let us not forget what our workers have done for us. Let us win this battle and reaffirm the trust in them again, and let us help everyone achieve their aspirations.

 

     Sir, with this, I support the motion.

Column:321

workers losing their jobs, even as we await for the first news of the H1N1 virus arriving at our shores, I am happy that the Government has not lost sight of ensuring the right fundamentals as we help soften the impact of any crisis on the population.

     Fundamentals are good because they are not only sound and ageless, they are often scaffolded by simple rules.  For example, to succeed in stocks, buy low sell high.  A very simple rule indeed; unfortunately many of us cannot do it.  In fact many of us cannot succeed because we cannot keep true to this maxim when market sentiments overwhelm.  My father taught me to spend no more than what I earn and to save for a rainy day.  Very sound too; but credit cards, overdraft facilities, "buy now pay later" schemes and many other clever financial schemes easily tempt us to finance our wants with future earnings we may not already have.

Column:322

successfully.  A good number of our youths, in my ward, I find out, drop out of school because they can get by, working at fast food chains for $4 an hour and leaving school immediately rather than wait for 12 long years of education to earn a basic trade certificate and in the process with much less pocket money.

     I believe that long-term success can only be ensured by sticking to principles and fundamentals.  This must not only be held by Government, but also by us all.  We may lose our jobs, but our children’s future must not also be lost by letting them pre-empt their education.  In a recession, as things get tougher and we have less money for certain luxuries and comforts that we have been used to, we must not lose sight to ensure our children continue to attend school and focus on their studies.  The gravest mistake that any of us as parents can do in our sorrow and depression when we lose our job or suffer a pay cut is to affect our children; in the extreme some may even encourage them to drop out of school on the mistaken belief that they may even be better off helping the family by starting work.  They can certainly find a job without completing school.  But by

Column:323

continuing and completing school, we will have prepared them for a career, not just for a job.

 

     Therefore, as we face this economic recession, we must not lose sight of our fundamentals.  The Government’s measures to soften the impact of the economic downturn and to prepare us for the eventual recovery will come to naught for us and our children, if we ourselves do not keep to the fundamentals both when we are in a crisis as well as when things are fine.  In fact, keeping to fundamentals during a crisis will help us to emerge even stronger, knowing well even it is the more difficult route.

Due to the fact that it did not indiscriminately overspend to gain popularity, it was able to have extra funds that were able to be compiled into the nation’s asset and used to fund the measures during this downturn. This emphasis on main and fundamental issues should not only be followed by all governments, but also to be reflected on by all of us.

 

Column:325

     These fundamental and basic issues can be easily understood but not many people can hold on to it well. For example, we acknowledge the importance of getting a proper and high standard of education. But how many are patient enough to go through 15 years of education with diligence and perseverance to reach university, while their households face difficulties?

 

     It is the same for meritocracy. The policy of meritocracy is fundamental in our nation’s development and has made everyone work hard to prove themselves. It has produced the Singaporeans’ work ethic and culture, including in Malay Singaporeans, that are admired and trusted in the eyes of the world. But some still complain that they lose out and always feel that meritocracy has been contaminated by discrimination. To me, even if there is discrimination, it is an inborn individual prejudice and not a systematic one, and can be overcome by proving our abilities and building trust. In fact, we have to be thankful that there are factors that give benefit to minorities, and that we are not burdened by barriers that are set up purposely and give advantages to a particular race only. What is there to complain, when Singaporean minorities are not forced to embrace the majority’s language and religion?  In Denmark, minorities are forced to absorb the Danish language; while in Sri Lanka, the Tamil minorities must master the Singhalese language, which is among the reasons that a civil war erupted. In fact, everyone in Singapore must speak English, even though there is no majority English race that is in power in Singapore. Why complain when our journey to improve our lives through education is not blocked on the basis of our origins? In fact, we are given support and assistance so that poverty will not hold anyone back. All Singapore schools have high standards and give equal treatment, so that our

Column:326

children can receive good education wherever they are schooling, even in schools that may not be considered as elite. This is not like many other countries where only the rich or the royalty can have the chance to receive quality education.

 

     In tertiary education, the Government is committed to give more university places, with the setting up of an institute that will give an advanced route for polytechnic graduates to obtain university degrees. In fact, those less well-off financially can get more help to continue schooling. I support President Nathan’s emphasis that education remains the best investment to guarantee Singapore’s and our children’s future. It is this basic policy, whether to encourage economic growth, close the income gap or build the future for the next generation, that education remains key.

 

     As we ride through this economic downturn, we must continue focusing on basic policies like giving emphasis on education. We may lose our jobs, but our children’s education is the one thing that we must not neglect. We may have less money to spend as luxuriously as we are used to, but we must ensure that our children remain in school and can focus their attention on their studies. The biggest mistake that we can make as parents is to let our confusion and situation become the reason for our children dropping out from school, or even encourage them with the wrong notion that is better for them to work to help out the family.

 

     It is true that our children can get jobs even without finishing school. But the Government realises that it is not enough to just create jobs. What is more reassuring is not the presence of jobs, but that our children are prepared to have careers. At the very least, our children must complete 10 years of education in primary and secondary schools, and get

Column:327

the ITE certificates, to help them continue upgrading themselves in their careers in the future.

 

     Two more groups that are far-sighted and held on patiently to fundamental principles will definitely be safe in this economic situation. My late father used to tell me not to spend more than what I earn and always save money. This is another fundamental principle that is easily accepted, but hard to follow. This downturn has woken up those who are faced with retrenchments; especially those who overspend beyond their means, do not have savings and in fact saddled with a lot of debts. Instead, those who think far, have savings and set aside some money each month, are not facing a lot of debts, and spend within their means, they must surely be in a better position to ride out this crisis. In fact, for some families, this is the time for them to think about investing for the sake of their families’ long-term well-being.

 

     For those who have "saved up" in terms of upgrading their job skills, that is by ensuring that they always possess the skills and qualifications that are needed by employers, and are aware of developments in the world economy – surely they now are more confident that their services are still needed by employers. This is apart from being more ready to accept job opportunities in new or emerging fields.

 

     In conclusion, today’s economic gloom will certainly bring many challenges and hurdles. But the storm will pass. In this downturn, we must hold on to main and fundamental issues, just as the Government has held on to the basic principles that have brought prosperity to Singapore so far. We must continue to focus on education, be prudent and spend within our means, as well as continue to upgrade our skills. With that, we can overcome this crisis successfully, and emerge in a stronger and steadier position than before. What is important is that the community must together grab the

Column:328

available opportunities, especially in the fields of education and jobs, so that no one in our community will be left behind once again when the country’s economy recovers.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports and Minister for Transport (Mr Teo Ser Luck): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for the opportunity to participate in this debate.


     The President's Address is comprehensive and thoughtful.  And he set in tone the right priorities and focus for the Government.  It rightly highlighted the work cut out for everyone in Singapore – both the necessary interim measures to tackle the immediate challenges and the long-term philosophy that has guided us well and will direct us into the future.


     The asset markets made some stunning recovery of late.  The blue chip stocks chalked up gains in the last one month as confidence seems to return in the US.  Property launches in Singapore seems to be selling better.


     But the latest economic indicators remained disturbing.  The Singapore economy registered a contraction of 14.6% in the first quarter compared with the previous quarter. This is better than

Column:329

the fall of almost 20% estimated just a month ago.  However, this marks the fourth straight quarter of contraction for Singapore.  We have suffered slowdowns and recessions before.  But this is the most extraordinary for an economy to contract by 14.6%.  Sir, the talk of green shoots may just be premature.  And I do not think we are out of the woods yet.


     The global economic crisis has, in some way, affected the political and economic thinking that have emerged.  I would like to share with Members some of my thoughts and concerns on some prevailing misconceptions and the need for continued progress and reforms in our system of politics, public policy and governance, particularly, the role of the Government and the electorate in our public policy formulation and implementation.


     The crises bring out the best and the worst in people.  The good thing is that most of them are well-intentioned.  For public policy practitioners around the world, there is always this inherent need to show that they have made visible changes to the policies and programmes during a crisis.  The notion of doing nothing or inaction is politically unacceptable.  Yet, there is also the risk of over-reaction where governments swing to the other extreme in policy responses.  In the US, we are already seeing some of the disturbing signs of government intervention in unprecedented proportions.  For example, there had been calls for the government to take more radical interventionist measures in interfering with executive pay or board matters.  We must resist the urge to do something radical, or even populist, just because we want to be seen doing something during crises.  Excessive reactions may lead us to losing sight of the right public agenda.


     What we must not forget is that we have done well with tested principles and

Column:330

policies.  We have delivered sound economic principles.  We must not let recent setbacks in the global markets detract us from our successful prudent economic formula that has served us well.


     Overseas, there is this increasingly misguided notion that globalisation has failed us.  Anti-trade and anti-globalisation lobbies – out of their self interests – have also seized on this agenda and attempt to derail real progress and they pronounce the failures of globalisation.  But let us not mistake that the current crisis is a failure of globalisation. We are still dependent on MNCs, free trade and global markets for growth.


     We do not need more regulations.  But we need better regulations. We would have failed if we fail to learn some of the lessons and build integrity in the market systems.


    The spate of Government interventions – be it nationalisations, bailouts, asset purchase or even equity injections – to me, they are merely standard operating procedures (SOPs) in crisis management for the financial markets.  They are pretty standard fare.  And the role of the Government must be tempered once the crisis is resolved.  What I mean is that big governments are not here to stay.  We must let market forces work.


     That said, there are indeed some takebacks from the current crisis.  I would like to highlight two. One, the need to diversify our global markets and lessen our reliance on the final destination of the usual markets like the US and G7 markets.  The crisis highlighted the fact that Asia is far from being decoupled from the US and the developed markets.  Singapore needs to step up efforts to build new capacity, capability and new sources of revenue to sustain our long-term economic growth. We need to spread our risks and explore new markets.


Column:331

     Second, we need to smoothen our economic cycles in managing the capital flows.  We need to deal with asset bubbles and economic swings more effectively.  Asset bubbles, in particular, tend to reward the community unequally.  But the US experience shows that excesses are created during good times.  Bad investments are made during good times.  Bad loans are also given during good times.  On the other hand, excessive regulations and controls implemented during the downturn may cause more economic hardship and risk sabotaging the recovery process.


    So we need to find the point of balance.  And it may not be appropriate to over-regulate on the way up and over-regulate on the way down.  Our public policy philosophy would have to incorporate the realities of the situation.  We must be bold enough to sometimes say that it is enough and we are going to slow you guys now, we are going to moderate.


     The financial crisis is not an excuse to look inwards.  Protectionism, as the President rightly pointed out, must be rejected outright.  While we restructure and retool our economy, we need to diversify our markets and risks, but we should never shut our doors to the external economies.  Globalisation has its setback.  But it will grow stronger as the developed countries impose better regulatory framework for trade and investments.  We must work even closer with our neighbours and other strategic partners for global economic solutions.  Because Singapore, with its open economy and experience, can help to lead some of the global discussions on economic reforms and even contribute to the new financial structure to build the new economic order.  We must provide the right checks and balances on some of the anti-trade movements, particularly

Column:332

those who want to see the free markets and to over-regulate economic activities.


     The global financial crisis should not affect our efforts to build a more efficient Government.  We must continue to build efficiencies in the public sector so that we do not have to over-tax the public eventually of the creative resources and energies that are possessed within.


     The Government must continue to reform its decision-making process in public policy formulation and implementation.  A participative engagement with the markets and constituents can more often than not produce better, if not more robust, policy decisions.


     The Government cannot be the sole provider of all public policy solutions.  It must not be too quick to abandon the process of sharing that decision-making process with the multiple stakeholders in finding the innovative solutions for the society.


     Leadership experts such as Dean Williams have proposed real leadership and what it meant was that real leadership comes from those who are able to mobilise communities they represent to confront real problems and issues facing them and provide innovative solutions so that everyone can achieve progress.  Simply said, the community solves the problems themselves.  So, real leadership is not about dominance and control. But it is to allow the community to take ownership.


     Authority alone is not enough to provide solutions for the country in the long term.  We must tap on the energies and creativity of the markets and the community for political, economic and social solutions. The complex globalisation process brings a lot of new dimensions and challenges to public policy making.  As such, we must reform our engagement process and expand the network and participative Government.


Column:333

     The multiple levels and breadth of Government and the wide network of interested stakeholders ensure that a single level of Government rarely has single power and influence over the way policies are designed, funded, managed and delivered.  Instead, the management of public sector programmes should involve a wide range of players from the people, public and private sectors.


     The fact is that Government officials may not always be the closest people to the market or public problems.  At times, a top-down approach may not work as effective.


     I heard of a story from a friend and this is a story about a small village, and it actually happened just recently in Thailand.  There was a community leader that was not every educated, but he successfully led a community-based research focus group and a resolution to a dispute over a water gate.  Because the dispute over the water gate had affected a large number of people and their livelihood, living both upstream and downstream at the Mekong River.  But what is important here is that the efforts to resolve the dispute over the shared water gate was largely driven by the community leaders with some help from the provincial and central governments, and it was the villagers who provided the technical solution to the disputed water gate, not the well-educated engineers from the department in the central government.  This community leader had little formal education.  He even started an innovative mini-savings scheme in his village to encourage their members to live their lives honestly, help one another and be self-reliant.  There are lessons to be learnt here, and we know that in some of our own communities and constituencies, our community leaders are doing the same.


Column:334

     Sir, in many of the public policy issues, a bottom-up approach can be just as effective.  Here, in Singapore, we can do that through different channels such as the grassroots organisation, Resident’s Committee, CDCs and the virtual space, we have portals such as REACH to reach out to the netizens too.  But, even so, I believe that the system needs to be reviewed for more effective engagement and participation in policy formulation.


     A more affluent and assertive community can only demand for more say, and they would demand for more say, in the public policy arena.  The elected and the bureaucracy must be prepared to expand that decision-making process.  Other community-based activities should be explored and expanded for the community to work out their own issues, problems and resolutions.  This is where our real leadership comes in during the adaptive and adjustment process where we must provide the guidance and wisdom to direct these communities in the right direction to change for progress.


     On a more practical level, the approach towards citizen engagement is important as we attempt to alleviate the hardship faced by the community, particularly the lower-income group. Are efforts and reliefs getting to the right targeted constituents?  How can we improve on the service delivery and policy evaluation?  The emergence of a dual economy and the widening income disparity, if not addressed, can produce cracks in the social fabric.  We need flexible and robust policy innovation and evaluation that can meet the real needs of people on the ground.  Above it all, empathy, compassion and flexibility are what our officers should possess.


     Singapore has succeeded by taking the route of the straight and narrow.  In times of crisis, we must go back to the basics again and, like some of my colleagues, we have a question on

Column:335

fundamentals and ask ourselves – what was it that has made us tick in the last 44 years?  What is essentially Singapore success and Singapore brand?  What was the differentiation that got us all here?


     Reliability is our brand and reality is where we should go. You want rule of law, good Government, financial stability, political stability, efficient communication, capital mobility, friendly tax regime, corruption-free market, educated and honest workforce, good public service and a safe location for your children.  You should come to Singapore.  That must always be our position in the global marketplace.


     But nothing would happen, whether now, in the past, or in the future without our people, our Singaporeans.  Human capital is all we have.  In a knowledge-based global economy, human capital becomes even more critical in the differentiation process.  We have built a nation of well-educated, honest and skilled people.  We have always believed that our education system will continue to produce them for renewal.  The international community has also endorsed our system and society too.  And the younger generation is a product of that system.  This is the fruits of labour.  And the fruit is ripe now and we should start to maximise the talents, creativity and potential of the generation.  Let us empower and embrace this new generation.  Give them a stake in the process to create change within and build the New Singapore for the future.  We must believe in them.  Because I am confident this power of belief would carry us through in the next 50 years, so that, together, we can build the New Singapore.

Column:337

Column:338

active in the workforce have already accepted pay reduction to continue to work.  They have no choice but to use the public transport during the peak hours.  I am sure if they have a choice, they would rather use the public transport during the non-peak hours.  I am hoping that the authorities and transport operators would consider waiving the travelling restrictions time for elderly and make their concession full day.
